An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-years [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and then dissolve parliament.<ref>Bloomberg. Breaking News.</ref> Celebrations and car honking was reported in Alexandria, as well as around Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive" /> The BBC reported celebratory gunfire in Gaza.
An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-years [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and then dissolve parliament.<ref>Bloomberg. Breaking News.</ref> Celebrations and car honking was reported in Alexandria, as well as around Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive" /> The BBC reported celebratory gunfire in Gaza.
  +   +
=== Post-Mubarak ===
  +
==== 12 February ====
  +
[[file:People celebrating the fall of Mubarak.ogg|thumb|People celebrating on the streets of Cairo]]A group of activists issued what they called the "People's CommuniquÃ© No 1", imitating the titles of communiquÃ©s from the Army. It demanded the dissolution of the cabinet Mubarak had appointed on 29 January; the suspension of the parliament elected late last year in a poll widely suspected of rigging; the creation of a transitional five-member presidential council made up of four civilians and one military person; the formation of a transitional government to prepare for an election to take place within nine months, and of a body to draft a new democratic constitution; freedom for the media and syndicates, which represent groups such as lawyers, doctors and engineers, and for the formation of political parties; and the scrapping of military and emergency courts. They announced the formation of a council to call and call off mass protests. <ref name="reuterscomm1">[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/12/us-egypt-protesters-idUSTRE71B17Q20110212 Egypt protest leaders vow to protect revolution]. Reuters. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011</ref><ref name="darnetcom1">[http://distributedresearch.net/blog/2011/02/13/army-protesters-egypt-democracy-communique-no-1-demands Egypt: Protesters Communique No 1 Demands to The Army]. Andy Roberts DARnet. 12 February 2011. Retrieved 13 February 2011.</ref>. The hours of [[curfew]] were reduced to between [[midnight]] and 6:00 Cairo local time.<ref name="aljazeera5">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/11/live-blog-feb-12-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 12 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
  +
The Egypt Supreme Council of the Armed Forces issued a ''communiquÃ©'' (CommuniquÃ© no. 4) in which they "promised to hand power to an elected, civilian government....[and] also pledged that Egypt would remain committed to all international treaties." <ref name="aljazeera5"/> [[Minister of Information]], [[Anas El-Fekky]] has been placed under [[house arrest]].<ref>{{cite web|author=David Batty |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/feb/12/egypt-day-after-mubarak-quits |title=Egypt the day after Mubarak quits - live | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> He later resigned from his position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/12/live-blog-feb-13-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 13 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
  +   +
Egypt's stock market regulator said the trading which was due to have started 13 February was delayed until 16 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LB984O3.html |title=Reopening of Egypt Exchange put off by 3 more days |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
  +   +
In a gesture of new beginning, thousands of people began cleaning up Cairo's central Tahrir Square, which had been trashed by 18 days of rallies by hundreds of thousands of protesters and sporadic street battles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBHFH00.html |title=Protesters press for voice in Egyptian democracy' |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
  +   +
==== 13 February ====
  +
The army stated that the Constitution was suspended.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egynews.net/wps/portal/news?params=115636 |title=Ø§ÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©: ØªØ¹Ø·ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙ Ø¨Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± ÙØ­Ù ÙØ¬ÙØ³Ù Ø§ÙØ´Ø¹Ø¨ ÙØ§ÙØ´ÙØ±Ù}}</ref><ref name="Leyne1">{{cite web|author=Jon Leyne |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12443678 |title=BBC News - Egyptian military dissolves parliament |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref><ref name="Deeb1">{{cite web|author=Sarah el Deeb|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LBUL700.html |title=Egypt's military rulers dissolve parliament |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> Parliament was dissolved and the military announced it would stay in power six months until [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential]] and [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2011|parliamentary elections]] could be held.<ref name=Leyne1/> The High Council of Egyptian Armed Forces had selected its chief to represent the council. The caretaker Cabinet appointed by Mubarak will remain until a new Cabinet is formed after elections.<ref name=Deeb1/>
  +   +
After an inventory was completed it was determined that a total of 18 artifacts from the Egyptian Museum are missing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LBRGK80.html |title=18 items missing from Egyptian Museum after unrest |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> About 70 objects were damaged.
  +   +
It was reported that secretary-general of the [[Arab League]] [[Amr Moussa]] was to stand down and run in the upcoming elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2011/02/11/feel_the_moussa_mentum |title=Feel the Moussa-mentum? | FP Passport |publisher=Blog.foreignpolicy.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref>
  +   +
==== 14 February ====
  +
Two representatives from the demonstrators, [[Wael Ghonim]] and [[Amr Salama]], met with spokespersons of the military and reported that there would be a [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|referendum on changes to the constitution]] within two months.<ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – 9 hours ago |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gyvIy92hyHZzDwY3N_T-NwAdrdeQ?docId=CNG.64b40623ef755670eb1e7e108c8d3448.801 |title=AFP: Egypt cyber activists say they met military rulers |publisher=Google.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref>
  +   +
Military rulers called for an end to strikes and protests. Thousands of state employees, including police, transit workers and ambulance drivers, protested for better pay. In a statement from the ruling military council there appeared to be a final warning to labor unions before the armed forces intervenes and imposes an outright ban on gatherings and strikes. In addition, the army cleared out most of the remaining demonstrators from Cairo's Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110214/D9LCKQL01.html Egyptian labor unrest grows after uprising]</ref>
